name: Book of Proverbs
shortDescription: The wisdom book of Solomon containing practical instruction for righteous living, a fountainhead of the Epistle of James and Jewish wisdom tradition
longDescription: The Book of Proverbs (Hebrew: Mishlei, meaning 'proverbs' or 'parables') is the central wisdom text of the Hebrew Bible, traditionally attributed to King Solomon, son of David. It contains collections of practical wisdom sayings (mashal) that teach the art of skillful living (chokmah). Proverbs stands at the head of Israel's wisdom literature tradition that includes Ecclesiastes, Job, and the apocryphal Wisdom of Solomon and Sirach. The book personifies Wisdom (Chokmah) as a divine feminine figure who was present at creation (Proverbs 8), inviting all to follow her ways. Unlike Torah's legal commandments, Proverbs offers moral instruction through observation of life, the natural world, and human relationships. Its teachings on controlling the tongue, the contrast between rich and poor, the dangers of anger, and the nature of true wisdom profoundly influenced the Epistle of James, which echoes Proverbs throughout. James 3:17 on 'wisdom from above' directly parallels Proverbs 2 on the path of wisdom. The opening command to 'fear the LORD' (Proverbs 1:7) establishes that true wisdom begins with reverence for God - a theme James the Just embodied through Torah-observant piety.

etymology.derivation: From Hebrew mashal meaning comparison, parable, or proverb

consensus.display: Core: 10th century BCE; Final form: post-exilic period

divisions.summary: Extended poems praising wisdom, warning against folly; personified Wisdom (Lady Wisdom) calls from the streets
Individual proverbs of Solomon - 375 sayings on righteous vs. wicked living
Two collections from unnamed sages; parallels Egyptian Instruction of Amenemope
More Solomonic proverbs copied by Hezekiah's scribes
Numerical proverbs and riddles from Agur son of Jakeh
Royal instruction and the 'Woman of Valor' (Eshet Chayil) poem

keyThemes.description: The beginning of wisdom is reverence for God (1:7, 9:10) - foundational to all moral instruction
keyThemes.jamesConnection: James emphasizes submission to God (James 4:7) and addresses 'the Lord' throughout

keyThemes.description: Two paths: wisdom leads to life, folly to destruction; personified as two women calling to the simple
keyThemes.jamesConnection: James 3:13-18 contrasts wisdom from above with earthly, demonic 'wisdom'

keyThemes.description: The tongue has power of life and death (18:21); the righteous guard their words (10:19, 13:3, 15:1-4)
keyThemes.jamesConnection: James 3:1-12 expands extensively on the tongue's destructive power - 'a fire, a world of iniquity'

keyThemes.description: Warnings against oppressing the poor (14:31, 22:22-23); poverty from laziness vs. injustice
keyThemes.jamesConnection: James 2:1-9 condemns partiality to the rich; James 5:1-6 pronounces woe on wealthy oppressors

keyThemes.description: A patient person is better than a warrior (16:32); hot temper causes strife (15:18, 29:22)
keyThemes.jamesConnection: James 1:19-20 commands 'be slow to anger; for human anger does not produce God's righteousness'

keyThemes.description: The wise hear instruction and do it (10:8); fools despise wisdom (1:7, 15:5)
keyThemes.jamesConnection: James 1:22-25 - 'Be doers of the word, not hearers only, deceiving yourselves'

keyThemes.description: The righteous walk on level paths (2:7-8, 4:18); the way of the wicked is like darkness
keyThemes.jamesConnection: James 5:19-20 on turning sinners from the error of their way

personifiedWisdom.description: Proverbs 1-9 personifies Wisdom (Chokmah) as a divine feminine figure who calls to humanity

keyPassages.content: Wisdom cries aloud in the streets, warning those who reject her
Wisdom present at creation, 'beside God as a master craftsman, daily his delight'
Wisdom builds her house with seven pillars and invites all to her feast

personifiedWisdom.theologicalSignificance: Lady Wisdom influenced later Jewish and Christian theology: identified with Torah in Sirach, with Christ as Logos in John 1, and with the Holy Spirit in some traditions

proverbsTeaching.content: If you seek wisdom like silver and search for it as for hidden treasures, then you will understand the fear of the LORD and find the knowledge of God. For the LORD gives wisdom.

jamesTeaching.content: But the wisdom from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle, open to reason, full of mercy and good fruits, impartial and sincere.

wisdomFromAbove.connection: Both texts describe divine wisdom as a gift from God with specific moral characteristics - James 3:17 reads like an expansion of Proverbs' wisdom teaching
